look.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to turn your eyes towards something, so that you can see it
look.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: We sneaked out while Jessie’s mom wasn’t looking.
If you look carefully you can see that the painting represents a human figure.
Gina covered her eyes, afraid to look.
‘It’s time we left, ’ Ian said, looking at his watch.
The men all turned to look at her as she entered the room.
Dad looked up from his paper and smiled.
‘We can’t go out in this weather, ’ said Bob, looking out of the window.
look.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: You look at someone or something
She was looking at the baby
She was looking to the baby
If you look to someone, you depend on them
He always looked to his father for advice
look.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I looked everywhere but Jimmy was nowhere to be found.
Could you help me look for my contact lens?
If you’re looking for a bargain, try the local market.
look.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: From the way things look at the moment, the Republicans are unlikely to win this election.
You made me look really stupid in front of all my friends!
It looks as if it might rain later.
It looks like they won’t be needing us anymore.
look.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: What did the man look like?
My sister doesn’t look anything like me.
You look tired. You should go to bed.
He looked as if he hadn’t washed for a week.
look.translation[0].definitions[3].note_: Look is a linking verb in meanings 3 and 4 This type of verb links the subject of the sentence with an adjective or noun
She made him look a fool
look.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: if a building looks in a particular direction, it faces that direction
look.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The cabin looks east, so we get the morning sun.
look.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to turn your eyes towards someone or something, so that you can see them
You should never look directly at the sun.
After a while, he turned and looked at me.
have/take a look
to look at something quickly, especially in order to find or check something
I’ll have a look in my desk.
Take a look at this!
glance
to look at someone or something for a short time and then look quickly away
Damien glanced nervously at his watch.
peek/peep
to look quickly at something – used especially when you are not supposed to look, or when you are looking through a small gap
The door was open so he peeked inside.
Katy peeped at her birthday present on the table.
peer
to look very carefully, especially because you cannot see well
Kenji was peering at the screen.
glare
to look at someone in an angry way
She glared at me as I got up to leave.
stare
to look at someone or something for a long time without moving your eyes
It’s rude to stare.
She stared straight into the camera.
gaze
to look at someone or something for a long time, often without realizing that you are doing it
She gazed out of the window.
He lay on his bed gazing at the ceiling.
gape
to look at someone or something for a long time, usually with your mouth open, because you are very shocked or surprised
People gaped at him with wide-open mouths.
regard
to look at someone or something, especially in a particular way
He regarded her steadily.
look.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: used to tell someone to look at something that you think is interesting, surprising etc
look.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: used to get someone’s attention so that you can suggest something or tell them something
look.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Look. Why don’t you think about it and give me your answer tomorrow?
Look, I’ve had enough of this. I’m going home.
look.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: an act of looking at something
look.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: I took one look at the coat and decided it wasn’t worth £50.
Let me have a look at that – I think it’s mine.
Take a good look at the photo and see if you recognize anyone in it.
I have a special interest in old houses. Do you mind if I take a look around?
look.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: an expression that you make with your eyes or face
look.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Why has Jake been giving me dirty looks (=unfriendly looks) all morning?
Mike gave him such a severe look he didn’t dare argue.
look.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: an act of examining something and thinking about it
look.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: I asked the vet to have a quick look at the puppies as well.
It’s time to take a fresh look at the old problem of low pay.
This month, take a long hard look (=examine very carefully) at where your money is going.
Have you had a chance to take a look at my proposal yet?
look.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: I can’t find them anywhere. Have a look yourself.
She had a good look (=searched carefully) through the files.
look.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: the appearance that someone or something has
look.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: The area has a very seedy look to it.
Mr Flynn had a tired, ill look in his eyes.
We should turn back now. It’s getting dark and I don’t like the look of those rain clouds.
not like the look of somebody/something
look.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: the way something seems to be
look.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: The neighbours are back from holiday by the looks of it (=that is how it seems).
I don’t like the look of this new policy  (=I do not like the way it seems).
look.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: a particular style in clothes, hair, furniture etc
look.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: The hippy look is back again.
look.translation[2].note_box[0].sections: an act of looking at something
Let me have a look at the map.
I took a quick look around the room.
glance
a quick look at something before looking away again
Susan cast a quick glance at me  (=she looked quickly at me).
He could not resist a sidelong glance   (=quickly looking to the side) to see what was happening on the other side of the road.
glimpse
a short look at someone or something in which you do not see them very clearly
Fans were hoping to catch a glimpse of the singer as he left the hotel.
I had only a fleeting glimpse   (=a very quick look) of the two men as they ran away.
gaze
a long steady look
Eddie fixed his gaze on the floor.
She looked up and met his gaze (=looked at him when he was looking at her).
stare
a long direct look, especially in an unfriendly way or in a way that shows you are surprised
He was watching me with a cold stare.
My cheery ‘Good Morning’ was met with a blank stare (=a stare which shows no emotion).
glare
an angry look at someone
She gave him a hostile glare as he entered the room.
frown
a confused or annoyed look
‘Anyway, ’ she said with a frown, ‘I don’t see how there could be a connection.’
